facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 759 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 759 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and Order dated June 26, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No, 92 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated June 26, 1957 in Appeal No. 92 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and Order dated June 26, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No, 92 of 1956. C. Bhatt, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshuar Nath and.P. L, Vohra, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellant is a cotton textile mill situated in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companyton textile mill situate in Bombay. It is said that the appellant had been companytinuously making losses from 1950 to 1955.

facts.text: Appellant had been continuously making losses from 1950 to 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the appellant had been companytinuously making losses from 1950 to 1955. References were however made under s. 73-A of the Act by the Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay,

facts.text: References made under s. 73-A of the Act by Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh for bonus for years 1952 and 1953 pending before Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: References were however made under s. 73-A of the Act by the Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay, in respect of disputes relating to bonus for the years 1952 and 1953, which are said to be pending before the Industrial Court, Bombay.

facts.text: Appellant's case before Industrial Court: no bonus payable due to losses.

anchor.surface_text: The ease of the appellant before the Industrial Court was that as it had made losses there was numberquestion of its paying any bonus for the years in dispute.

facts.text: Agreement arrived between Mill-owners Association, Bombay and Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh for bonus 1952-1957.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that while the references were pending, an agreement was. arrived at between the Mill-owners Association, Bombay and the Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay, with respect to payment of bonus for the years 1952 to 1957

facts.text: Clause 6 of agreement provided minimum bonus of 4-8% even if inadequate profit or actual loss, adjustable later.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  6  of that agree- ment provided for payment of bonus even where the profit made by a mill was number adequate to provide for all prior charges as per the Full Bench formula... minimum bonus being in either of these two cases 4-8 per cent.

facts.text: Agreement registered and enforceable as award against signing mills.

anchor.surface_text: This agreement was registered and was made enforceable as an award against those mills which were parties thereto. The appellant however did number sign the agreement

facts.text: Appellant did not sign the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant however did number sign the agreement and therefore it was number enforced as an award by the Industrial Court against the appellant.

facts.text: Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh requested Government to enforce award against appellant under s.114(2).

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh wrote to the Government of Bombay requesting that the  1  1930 2 L.L.J. 1247. said award should be enforced against the appellant in exercise of the powers vested in the Government by s. 114 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Government of Bombay issued notification dated July 31, 1956 directing enforcement of award dated March 13, 1956 for bonus 1952-1957 against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: After necessary action under s. 114 2 , the Government of Bombay issued a numberification dated July 31, 1956, directing that the award made by the Industrial Court on March 13, 1956, for payment of bonus for the years 1952 and 1953 and also for the years 1954 to 1957 be enforced against the appellant.

facts.text: Award made by Industrial Court on March 13, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: ...the award made by the Industrial Court on March 13, 1956, for payment of bonus for the years 1952 and 1953 and also for the years 1954 to 1957 be enforced against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Bombay High Court challenging constitutionality of s.114(2) and the notification.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a writ petition by the appellant in the High Court challenging the companystitutionality of s. 114 2  and also challenging the power of the State Government to issue such a numberification under that provision.

facts.text: Writ petition dismissed by Bombay High Court on October 9, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was however dismissed on October 9, 1956.

facts.text: Appeal to Division Bench of Bombay High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: There was then an appeal to a Division Bench of the High Court in which also the appellant failed.

facts.text: Certificate granted by High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for a certificate to enable it to file an appeal to this Court, which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on February 16, 1961 by Wanchoo J. (majority).

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 16. The Judgment of Gajendragadkar, Subba Rao, Wanchoo and Mudholkar, JJ., was delivered by Wanchoo, Sarkar, J., delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds notification dated July 31, 1956 beyond powers under s.114(2), sets it aside.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned numberification therefore must be held to be bad inasmuch as it goes beyond the powers companyferred on the State Government under s. 114 2  and must therefore be struggle down.

facts.text: Appellant mill member of Mill-owners Association but did not accept agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1, 1956, while these references were pending, the Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Singh entered into an agreement with the Mill Owners Association, Bombay, of which fortyseven companyton textile mills including the appellant mill, were members,

facts.text: Agreement dated March 1, 1956 between union and Mill Owners Association.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1, 1956, while these references were pending, the Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Singh entered into an agreement with the Mill Owners Association, Bombay,

facts.text: About 42 mills accepted the agreement individually.

anchor.surface_text: This agreement was subsequently accepted individually by about fortytwo of the mills who were members of the Association and parties to the references,

facts.text: Appellant mill did not accept the agreement, no award made concerning it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant mill did number accept the agreement and numberaward was made in the references companycerning it and so far as it was companycerned, the references remained pending.

Section. 114 2  reads as follows.- In cases in which a Representative Union is a party to a, registered agreement, or a settlement, submission or award, the State Government may, after giving the parties affected an opportunity of being heard, by numberification in the Official Gazette, direct that such agreement, settlement, submission or. award shall be binding upon such other employers and employees in such industry or occupation in that local area as may be specified in the numberification Provided that before giving a direction under this section the State Government may, in such cases as it deems fit, make a reference to the Industrial Court for its opinion.

anchor.surface_text: Section. 114 2  reads as follows.- In cases in which a Representative Union is a party to a, registered agreement, or a settlement, submission or award, the State Government may, after giving the parties affected an opportunity of being heard, by numberification in the Official Gazette, direct that such agreement, settlement, submission or. award shall be binding upon such other employers and employees in such industry or occupation in that local area as may be specified in the numberification Provided that before giving a direction under this section the State Government may, in such cases as it deems fit, make a reference to the Industrial Court for its opinion.

arguments.claim: State Government's power under s.114(2) is co-terminus with the power of an adjudicator under the Act; cannot direct what an Industrial Court cannot award.

holdings.text: the State Governments power to make a direction under that section is co-terminus with the power of an adjudicator be it a labour court, an Industrial Court or a wage board under the Act to make an award thereunder, and the State Government cannot under s. 114 2 do what an adjudicator cannot do under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, as we read a, 114 2 we cannot escape the conclusion that the State Governments power to make a direction under that section is co-terminus with the power of an adjudicator  be it a labour court, an Industrial Court or a wage board under the Act  to make an award thereunder, and the State Government cannot under s. 114 2  do what an adjudicator cannot do under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power under s.114(2) interpreted in light of Act's scheme, s.95A binding precedents, and equality of agreement/award/settlement; government cannot exceed adjudicatory powers.

holdings.text: The impugned notification therefore must be held to be bad inasmuch as it goes beyond the powers conferred on the State Government under s. 114 2 and must therefore be struck down.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned notification therefore must be held to be bad inasmuch as it goes beyond the powers conferred on the State Government under s. 114 2  and must therefore be struck down.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification enforces award requiring minimum bonus despite inadequate profits or losses, contrary to binding precedents (Associated Cement Companies, New Manekchowk Spinning) that Industrial Court cannot award bonus without available surplus.

holdings.text: We therefore allow the appeal with costs and setting aside the order of the High Court hold that the notification dated July 31, 1956, is beyond the powers of the State Government under s. 114 2 and direct that it will not be enforced.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal with costs and setting aside the order of the High Court hold that the notification dated July 31, 1956, is beyond the powers of the State Government under s. 114 2  and direct that it will not be enforced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispositive order based on ultra vires finding; preserves pending bonus references.

holdings.text: Section 114 2 places a registered agreement, a settlement, a submission and an award on the same footing and so if an award has to conform to s. 95-A as it must so must the other three mentioned therein.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, s. 114 2  places a registered agreement, a settlement, a submission and an award on the same footing and so if an award has to conform to s. 95-A as it must so must the other three mentioned therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading equates instruments under s.114(2), subjecting all to Act's legal constraints including s.95A.

holdings.text: It would not be open to an Industrial Court to grant bonus when profit was not adequate to meet all prior charges or where there was an actual loss.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant is that it would not be open to an Industrial Court to grant bonus when profit was not adequate to meet all prior charges or where there was an actual loss

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted appellant's contention based on Supreme Court precedents applying Full Bench formula.

holdings.text: s. 114 2 confers unguided and arbitrary power [rejected]. The power given by the provision is not, in my view, uncontrolled.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants first challenge the validity of the section on the ground that it offends Art. 14 of the Constitution. It seems to me that this contention is not well-founded. The power given by the provision is not, in my view, uncontrolled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power guided by industrial peace in defined local area involving representative union; not arbitrary.

holdings.text: the section offends Art. 19 1 g in that it puts an unreasonable restriction [rejected].

anchor.surface_text: The next objection to the section is that it offends Art. 19 1 g  in that it puts an unreasonable restriction ... Therefore, it seems to me that the restrictions imposed by s. 114 2  cannot be said to be unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions reasonable for industrial peace; minimum bonus adjustable, akin to accepted wage laws.

holdings.text: the section was quite within the legislative competence of the legislature which passed it.

anchor.surface_text: I also feel no doubt that the section was quite within the legislative competence of the legislature which passed it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed valid exercise of legislative power; no challenge mounted effectively.

holdings.text: there is really no proceeding held within the meaning of s. 95 A in connection with the issue of the notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification issuance not a 'proceeding' raising question of law; s.95A confined to adjudications.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory bar; Act permits notifications independently.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned numberification therefore must be held to be bad inasmuch as it goes beyond the powers companyferred on the State Government under s. 114 2  and must therefore be struggle down. We therefore allow the appeal with costs and setting aside the order of the High Court hold that the notification dated July 31, 1956, is beyond the powers of the State Government under s. 114 2  and direct that it will number be enforced.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed with costs; High Court order set aside; notification dated July 31, 1956 held beyond powers under s. 114(2) and quashed; not to be enforced.
directions: This decision will not prejudice the trial of any references with respect to bonus which may be pending or which may hereafter be made between the appellant and its employees with respect to years 1952 to 1957 both inclusive.
If such references are pending or are hereafter made they will be decided in accordance with the decision of this Court in The Associated Cement Companies Case
